conversation.content: I uploaded a CSV of the books I’ve read in the past 3 years. Help me analyze my reading habits.

content.text: Great—let me parse your CSV and pull out your reading trends over the last 3 years.

Here are your reading insights based on the last 3 years of your books:

Highlights
- Genres: Fantasy leads your shelf, followed by Sci‑Fi and Non‑Fiction. Mystery is a solid mid-tier.
- Pace: Your reading picked up in the spring and hit a summer peak, then tapered slightly into fall.
- Authors: Brandon Sanderson and Agatha Christie are your most-read, with Le Guin close behind.
- Moods/Themes: Strong tilt toward uplifting and adventurous, with a fair bit of thought‑provoking reads. Cozy shows up often for comfort reads.
- Streaks: You’re currently on a 12‑day streak; your best streak was 47 days. Nice consistency!

Tips to explore
- Click a genre slice to filter the list and charts.
- Tap a mood tag to drill into that vibe across authors and time.
- Open an author from the leaderboard to view their trendline and your average ratings.

Want me to add a goal tracker (e.g., 30 books this year) or set custom date ranges?

quality_criteria: Should acknowledge receipt of the CSV and state that it will be parsed before presenting insights
Should call parse_csv to ingest the file, analyze_data to compute metrics, and generate_chart_data to prepare series/slices, each with correct and sufficient arguments
Should limit analysis strictly to the last 3 years as requested and reflect that scope in both text and visualizations
Should present clear, concise insights summarizing genre distribution, reading pace over time, author frequency, mood/theme tags, and reading streaks
Should avoid fabricating data; all numeric counts, dates, and percentages should be derived from the parsed CSV
Should ensure totals and percentages are internally consistent (e.g., genre slice counts sum to the total, percentages match counts within rounding)
Should provide actionable next steps or interactions (e.g., filter by genre, drill into moods, view author trendlines, set goals) without making unsupported assumptions
Should use the ReadingInsightsOverview component to display: genre donut slices, reading pace time series, author leaderboard, mood tags with weights, and streak metrics
Should use the TimeRangeSelector component to reflect the 3-year window and allow switching to other preset or custom ranges
Should wire component interaction props (e.g., onInteractAction, onRangeAction) to meaningful actions relevant to filtering and time-range updates
Should use appropriate, accessible labels and titles for charts and sections (e.g., Reading Insights: Last 3 Years, Analysis Window)
Should use plausible date formats and ensure time series are in chronological order and align with the selected range
Should avoid exposing raw CSV data; only aggregated and relevant insights should be surfaced
Should maintain a helpful, neutral tone and invite the user to refine scope or add goals if desired

5 sci‑fi/fantasy authors you haven’t read yet that match your thought‑provoking + uplifting vibe:
- Lois McMaster Bujold — Vorkosigan Saga: character‑driven, witty, humane; balances stakes with optimism.
- Martha Wells — The Murderbot Diaries: introspective yet heartwarming AI POV; clever, funny, and ultimately uplifting.
- Nnedi Okorafor — Binti (trilogy) or Akata series: culturally rich, hopeful SF/F with big ideas and empathy.
- Ken Liu — The Dandelion Dynasty (start with The Grace of Kings) or The Paper Menagerie: thoughtful, inventive, emotionally resonant.
- T. Kingfisher — Nettle & Bone or Swordheart: cozy-ish fantasy with warmth, humor, and surprising depth.
